greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = 2^n mod 11.
comment: a(k) = k has only one solution, namely k=7. - _Jon Perry_, Oct 30 2014
As 2 is a primitive root of 11, all integers 1 through 10 are present. - _Jon Perry_, Oct 30 2014
reference: H. Cohn, A Second Course in Number Theory, Wiley, NY, 1962, p. 256.
I. M. Vinogradov, Elements of Number Theory, pp. 220 ff.
link: Vincenzo Librandi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (1,0,0,0,-1,1).
formula: a(n+5) = 11 - a(n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Oct 17 2018
program: (Sage) [power_mod(2,n,11) for n in range(0, 78)] # _Zerinvary Lajos_, Nov 03 2009
(MAGMA) [Modexp(2, n, 11): n in [0..100]]; // _G. C. Greubel_, Oct 16 2018
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
